challenges.title: Introduction to Web Storage API
description: The Web Storage API allows for the storage of key value pairs in the browser.

The Web Storage API can store values using two different systems, sessionStorage and localStorage.

  • sessionStorage is a storage area for the duration of the page session (as long as the browser is open and is removed when the browser is closed).
  • localStorage persists even when the browser is closed and reopened.

The Web Storage API extends the Window object with two properties â€” Window.sessionStorage and Window.localStorage.

These two objects implement the Storage interface.

There is also Window.onstorage event handler that fires when a storage area changes.
For these challenges we will use localStorage.

challenges.title: Storage.setItem()
description: The setItem() method of the Storage interface, when passed a key name and value, will add that key to the storage, or update that key's value if it already exists.
storage.setItem(keyName, keyValue);
For example:
The following creates two data items inside local storage.

localStorage.setItem('bgcolor', 'red');
localStorage.setItem('font', 'Helvetica');
Values can also be set by using array notation and assignment.

localStorage['bgcolor'] = 'red';
localStorage['font'] = 'Helvetica';
<hr>

Add a click mouse event to the save button.
In the event handler use local storage to save the background color value with the key background-color.
Before running the test, click the save button to save the value to local storage.

tests.text: When clicking save your code should save a storage item to local storage with a key name of background-color.
tests.testString: assert(code.match(/localStorage\[["|']background-color["|']\]\s*?=|localStorage\.setItem\(["|']background-color["|'],/gi), 'message: Set a local storage item to localStorage with the key background-color.');

challenges.title: Storage.getItem()
description: The getItem() method of the Storage interface, when passed a key name, will return that key's value.
var aValue = storage.getItem(keyName);
For example:
The following creates two data items inside local storage.

var currentColor = localStorage.getItem('bgcolor');
var currentFont = localStorage.getItem('font');
You can also get values by using array notation.

var currentColor = localStorage['bgcolor'];
var currentFont = localStorage['font'];
<hr>
Add a click mouse event to the load button and load the background color value into the background color textbox with the key background-color.

tests.text: There should be a local storage item with a key name of background-color from the last lesson.
tests.testString: assert(code.match(/=\s*?localStorage\[["|']background-color["|']\]|=\s*?localStorage\.getItem\(["|']background-color["|'],/gi), 'message: Get a value from a local storage item with the key background-color.');

challenges.title: Other Storage Methods
description: The full API for Storage can be found here .
These methods include removeItem (for removing a single item by key) and clear (for removing all items).
For example:
The following removes an item from local storage.
localStorage.removeItem('bgcolor');
<hr>
Add a click mouse event to the remove button and remove the background color item with the key background-color.

tests.text: When clicking remove the local storage item with a key name of background-color should be removed from local storage.
tests.testString: assert(code.match(/localStorage\.removeItem\(["|']background-color["|']/gi), 'message: Remove the local storage item with the key background-color.');
